sub_topic: Examining the detectability of gravitational waves from a population of binary white dwarfs.
message_1: What is the expected rate of detection for the LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) mission for gravitational waves emitted by binary white dwarf systems in our galaxy, based on the population of known binary white dwarf systems?
message_2:
The expected rate of detection for LISA for gravitational waves emitted by binary white dwarf systems in our galaxy depends on several factors, including the sensitivity of the instrument, the number of detectable sources, and the characteristics of the binary white dwarf systems.

According to recent studies and simulations, LISA is expected to detect thousands of binary white dwarf systems in our galaxy. A study by Korol et al. (2017) estimates that LISA will detect around 25,000 binary white dwarf systems with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) greater than 7. Another study by Breivik et al. (2018) predicts that LISA will observe about 9,000 detached binary white dwarf systems and around 2,000 interacting systems.

These numbers are based on the current understanding of the population of binary white dwarf systems in our galaxy, as well as the expected sensitivity of LISA. However, it is important to note that these estimates are subject to change as our knowledge of the binary white dwarf population and LISA's capabilities improve.

In summary, based on the population of known binary white dwarf systems, LISA is expected to detect thousands of gravitational wave signals from these systems in our galaxy. The exact number will depend on the final sensitivity of the instrument and our understanding of the binary white dwarf population.

1. Korol, V., Rossi, E. M., & Groot, P. J. (2017). The gravitational wave background from Galactic double white dwarfs: LISA mission estimates. Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, 470(4), 4453-4463.
